awd_titl_txt: Conference: 2024 Conference on Science at Sanford Underground Research Facility
awd_abstract_narration:
This is an award to help participants attend the 2024 Conference on Science at Sanford Underground Research Facility (CoSSURF 2024) conference May 14, 2024 – May 17, 2024 at the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology, Rapid City, South Dakota. The support will be used to more fully enable participation by early career members and students. The conference will allow participants to disseminate results and have discussions surrounding the latest progress in science enabled by the low radioactive background of the underground facility including searches for dark matter, rare decays of isotopes, and accelerator based studies of neutrinos. These topics are aligned with NSF scientific program areas with the Physics Division.

This award will help fund participation in the conference by providing travel support to enable a wider range of participants with support going to early career scientists including those from underrepresented groups. These scientists will have the opportunity to present and obtain feedback by presenting at the conference (talk or poster). Furthermore, these scientists will benefit from discussions with other scientists working on similar topics and thus will transfer useful knowledge. This project is jointly funded by the experimental particle, particle astrophysics, and nuclear physics as well as the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 5th Conference on Science at the Sanford Underground Research Facility (SURF) took place from May 14th to 17th, 2024, at the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology in Rapid City, South Dakota. This NSF-supported event drew eighty participants from across the globe, facilitating rich discussions on the current and prospective scientific projects at SURF in Lead, South Dakota.

The conference featured morning plenary talks and afternoon parallel sessions, covering topics such as neutrino oscillations with a focus on the Deep Underground Neutrino Experiment (DUNE), dark matter searches through the LUX-Zeplin (LZ) experiment, neutrinoless double beta-decay (Majorana Demonstrator and LEGEND), nuclear astrophysics (CASPAR), and research in geology and biology. The breadth of topics ensured comprehensive coverage of research activities related to SURF, alongside other globally significant experiments.

The event commenced with a welcome address from the Vice President of Research at South Dakota Mines and was highlighted by a presentation from SURF's Community Relations Specialist. This talk provided valuable insights into the history of the Black Hills and the ongoing community engagement initiatives, emphasizing the importance of respecting the local Lakota community's cultural ties to the area. Dr. Jaret Heise, the Science Director at SURF, presented a detailed report on the current state of the facility and future plans, particularly regarding the upcoming excavations necessary for the DUNE project. The conference concluded with a well-received guided tour of the underground laboratory on May 17th.

Incorporated into the conference was a SURF users meeting, which significantly enhanced the event by fostering research collaboration and networking. This integration proved instrumental in sharing findings, discussing challenges, and strategizing future research endeavors, vital for advancing SURF's scientific agenda and reinforcing a cohesive research community.

Furthermore, with the support of the National Science Foundation, travel awards were granted to two young researchers, enhancing the participation of emerging scientists. This initiative not only facilitated a dynamic exchange between experienced and next-generation scientists but also significantly contributed to the success of the conference.
